Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER--Condensed Matrix Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization (cMALDI) Towards Online Detection of Viral Nucleic Acids and Proteins in Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
This high-risk, high-reward EAGER project is focused on developing an instrument that can be used to detect viruses and viral fragments associated with atmospheric aerosols in real time in the field. The development of this instrument represents the first step towards answering a number of questions about the modes of atmospheric transport for viruses associated with submicron particles. It is hoped that the instrument will eventually find application in airborne virus monitoring.

The instrument to be developed is a condensation matrix assisted laser desorption ionization-aerosol time-of-flight mass spectrometer (cMALDI-ATOFMS). This instrument is expected to provide measurements of the size-resolved number fraction of airborne aerosols containing viruses or viral fragments, using in-flight laser desorption/ionization-time-of-flight mass spectrometry. The effort includes the development and optimization of a three-stage condensation system (cMALDI) to grow submicron, virus-laden particles to the aerodynamically and optically large sizes, needed for ATOFMS optical detection. Laboratory experiments using the cMALDI system will be used to develop calibrations utilizing mixtures of proteins and nucleic acids incorporated into monodisperse submicrometer-to-supermicrometer test particles. These mixtures will be nebulized and used as tests to tune the ATOFMS settings towards biomolecular detection. Individual, bare viruses will be aerosolized via electrospray, such that the signal from a virus is clearly distinguished from background molecules. If successful, these will be the first measurements enabling virus detection at the single aerosol particle level via mass spectrometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between atmospheric chemists at University of California San Diego and mechanical engineers at the University of Minnesota aimed to develop an innovative online mass spectrometry tool capable of real-time detection of individual viruses down to 20 nm by integrating matrix assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) and single particle mass spectrometry. Commonly, MALDI is employed with samples that have been collected and processed prior to chemical analysis. With the technique developed as a result of this project, the concept of MALDI has been applied to capture the real-time chemical composition of single particles, eliminating the need for sample collection and preparation. A sublimation-condensation growth system was designed and characterized at University of Minnesota specifically for the growth of nanometer size particles using low vapor pressure solids. The system can grow particles as low as 7 nm to sizes that are suitable for optical detection (i.e. 200-400 nm), a method used by most aerosol measurement instruments and detected in situ using Aerosol Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer (ATOFMS). Three different organic matrices (2,4 dihydroxybenzoic acid, ferulic acid, and 1,8-bis(tetramethylguanidino)naphthalen (TMGN)) were tested to determine the range and reproducibility of the system, as well as to characterize the growth patterns experienced by particles in the system. Particle growth was found to be most dependent on the matrix and temperature of the sublimation region. The matrix TMGN resulted in the most particle growth at the lowest temperatures and the least amount of mass spectral interference, making it the most appealing choice for chemically complex samples. The integrated system, using the matrix TMGN, was utilized in several experiments including chemically analyzing secondary organic aerosols, detecting sub 200 nm sea spray aerosols, and detention of organic species during a phytoplankton bloom. The development, implementation, and application of the innovative condensation matrix assisted ATOFMS system (referred to as cMA-ATOFMS), allows characterization of small particles, including viruses, and detection of organic compounds within sub-200 nm particles while minimizing fragmentation effects.
